newsitem.title: USA: Oracle unit completes Navio acquisition.
newsitem.headline: Oracle unit completes Navio acquisition.

text.p: Oracle Corp.'s Network Computer Inc. unit said Tuesday it completed the acquisition of Navio Communications Inc. and was now poised to take on Microsoft Corp.'s WebTV with its own Web-browsing device for television sets.

The Oracle unit, a developer of cheap computing devices called network computers, said Thomson Consumer Electronics Inc.'s RCA unit and other electronics companies will have a Web-browsing settop box based on its technology ready for Christmas.

The $300 devices, based on Network Computer's so-called Enchanced TV technology, will let TV viewers pull up World Wide Web sites, send and receive electronic mail, view electronic TV program guides and eventually play online game shows.

The Network Computer product would compete against WebTV Networks Inc., the settop-box designer that Microsoft bought for $425 million two months ago. Each company is trying to get a say in the development of an upcoming generation of TV sets that combine video broadcast with online content.

"Our goal is to have as many settop boxes, game consoles and television sets have the Enhanced TV software to deliver a more compelling experience," said David Limp, Network Computer director of consumer marketing.

Analysts estimate that there are between 300 million to 1 billion television sets in the world. Software companies could strike a huge new source of revenue if the next generation of TVs relied on their products.

Network Computer is a unit of database software company Oracle. It is developing cheap computers that draw their computing power from corporate networks or the Internet, and do not rely on software from Microsoft.
In May, Network Computer said it would buy Navio, an affiliate of Internet software company Netscape Communications Corp., to develop consumer versions of these so-called network computers.
